channel.title: Instant-Screen Grabbing Programs
channel.description: Alright, so Screensnapr has been a pain in the ass for some time now, the servers have been down for so long! I'm in need of another one, so does anyone know of one?

item.title: Instant-Screen Grabbing Programs
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Ix Soulcist xI, post:3, topic:445831”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=548688.msg4022192#msg4022192 date=1340088078]
Gyazo is quite nice. The only problem with it is that you have to be able to run the program while you’re in another program. Luckily for me, my keyboard has hotkeys for running programs whenever I want. It works well in my scenario
[/quote]
Yeah, that’s the problem, I can’t hit a hot key to start it, I have to go to the desktop and click it and then capture the picture, and I don’t know how to set a hotkey for it as it seems there aren’t any settings.[/quote]
If using alt+tab as a window changer isn’t working for you, I suppose you could try setting up a custom windows hotkey.

How to assign a hotkey to an application

Open the Start menu
Find the application in the All Programs menu
Right-click the desired program file and choose “Properties”
In the Properties dialog, find the text box labeled “Shortcut key”
Click in the text box and enter a key that you wish to use in your hotkey. Windows will automatically place “Ctrl + Alt +” in front. If you choose a function key or a numeric keypad key, only that key will be used and “Ctrl + Alt +” will not be added.
Click “OK”
How to assign a hotkey to a folder or file not in the All Programs menu

Create a shortcut file by right-click dragging the desired target file or folder to the Desktop (or to a folder on the Desktop) and choose “Create shortcuts here” from the right-click menu. (You can also use “Send to” but that will be covered in an upcoming tip.) You must create the shortcut exactly where you intend to keep it. If you create the shortcut one place and then move it, the hotkey won’t work,
Right-click the new shortcut file and choose “Properties”
Carry out steps 4-6 given above.

http://www.techsupportalert.com/content/how-create-custom-hotkey-your-favorite-application-or-folder.htm

Read full topic

item.title: Instant-Screen Grabbing Programs

eyeownyew:

Gyazo is quite nice. The only problem with it is that you have to be able to run the program while you’re in another program. Luckily for me, my keyboard has hotkeys for running programs whenever I want. It works well in my scenario

Yeah, that’s the problem, I can’t hit a hot key to start it, I have to go to the desktop and click it and then capture the picture, and I don’t know how to set a hotkey for it as it seems there aren’t any settings.
